data.text: Caught in 3 Massive Thunderstorms while Camping on a Bike Tour!

Hey everyone. So I’m biking across America, east coast to west coast, sleeping in a small bivvy tent. I’ve been caught in 3 massive thunderstorms, directly above me during the night while in the night. Lightening and thunder cracking at the same time right on top of me. Was scared shitless to say the least. Doesn’t feel very wise or safe and take that risk of being struck and potentially dying. Anyone have any advice? I’ve never felt so vulnerable and helpless, just curled in a ball waiting for the lightening to strike me dead haha
Don't sleep under Oak trees - the bark pattern holds water and conducts lightening well....

data.text:
1. Avoid empty fields in a thunderstorm where you are the tallest object. 2. Avoid lone trees, edge of a forest, river banks, or high ridges or above treeline (go as deep inside of a forest as you can. 3. Park bike away from you. It can acts as a lightening rod though the reality is, anything can attract lighting regardless what it's made from. Lightening looks for the nearest object it can reach. If there is nothing, it hits the ground. 4. Not sure this works but I use an extendable metal hiking pole to hold my bike as a kick stand from under the seat. A few times camping above tree line, I fully extended it and stuck it in the ground far from me to act as a lightening rod with the bike in the opposite direction to give the lightening a few different objects besides my tent - this could just be psychological to make me feel safer - I have no science to back it up though I once wanted to invent a special retractable light lightening rod for bike tourers (I'm sure in the future someone with time and money will manufacture it if the market is big enough). 4. Use a tent. Psychologically we feel more secure in it than in a bivvy but more importantly, in a tent, you can isolate better - and not be wet or uncomfortable or as scared - if the storm is close. Sit in the center with shoes on. If you have an air pad even better (the Big Anges I use is 3 inches thick when filled and packs small and light) as it keeps you isolated from the ground should the tent or ground near you get hit it reduces the odds of it jumping on you. 5. Most important: count the seconds between lightening and thunder. Multiple it by the sonic number (342). That will give you the most accurate distance in meters. If 9 seconds or more you are safe - it's 3km away.. If 6 seconds it's getting closer at 2km away. 3 seconds it's 1km away - it's getting dangerous. 1. Second it's 342 meters away but let's just round down to 300 meters, about 1000 feet. Seek proper shelter or follow the previous instructions. Usually thunderstorms go away as quickly as they come if that's a relief. But the best prevention is preparation. Find a weather app you like/trust and check for thunderstorms. Here are the "top 5": https://www.miops.com/blogs/news/5-best-real-time-lightning-strike-map-apps-and-websites-for-photographers

If you are in a thunderstorm, do not lay on the ground as the current can travel along the ground and be deadly up to 100 ft. Stay away from water and trees. Being off the ground is a good idea and removing metal objects from your person will reduce injury if the worst does happen. The CDC advised… “If no shelter is nearby, crouch down into a ball-like position with your head tucked and hands over your ears and your feet closely together” https://www.cdc.gov/disasters/lightning/faq.html

data.text: We're doing South to North at the moment and have been caught in a few of the big southern monsoonal lightning storms. We see them coming, set up camp in an area that's as low as possible that won't flood or even a road cutting for example or near a set of low trees yet avoiding the highest trees. We inflate our plastic air mattresses, wack our ear buds in and eat sacrificial Gummy Bears (as offering to the Gods). The fact you're dry, raised off the ground, with higher objects around means the lightning is much less likely to find a pass of least resistance through you.
